[[Buddhism]] sets [[Upādāna|attachment]] and [[Taṇhā|desire]] as negative emotions that release [[anger]] and cause suffering; love and [[ego]] are incompatible. In the buddhist philosophy, true love is compassionate love.<ref name="Buddha">[http://books.google.es/books?id=VECepVHTH0QC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Guatama Buddha. ''The Dhammapada''. Translated by Irving Babbitt.]</ref> [[Jesus Christ]] also embraces love from an [[altruism|atruistic]] and compassionate view (“love your neighbor as yourself”). [[Gottfried Leibniz]] states that “to love is to place our happiness in the happiness of another”.

[[Sigmund Freud]] thinks that unconditional love from a mother leads to perpetual dissatisfaction: "When you were incontestably the favorite child of your mother, you keep during your lifetime this victor feeling, you keep feeling sure of success, which in reality seldom doesn’t fulfill". He describes love as a [[narcissism|narcissistic]] behavior; human beings only love what they were, what they are, what they want to be.

[[Humanistic psychology]] sets healthy [[self-esteem in humanistic psychology|self-esteem]] as an essential requirement for every healthy interpersonal relationship, including interpersonal love. [[Abraham Maslow]] places love at the ''love/belonging level'', between the ''safety level'' and the ''esteem level'', in his [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|hierarchy of needs]].

===Comparison of scientific models===
 
===Comparison of scientific models===
 
Biological models of love tend to see it as a mammalian drive, similar to [[hunger]] or [[thirst]].<ref name="Lewis"/> Psychology sees love as more of a social and cultural phenomenon. There are probably elements of truth in both views. Certainly love is influenced by [[hormone]]s (such as [[oxytocin]]), [[neurotrophins]] (such as [[Nerve Growth Factor|NGF]]), and [[pheromone]]s, and how people think and behave in love is influenced by their conceptions of love. The conventional view in [[biology]] is that there are two major drives in love: [[sexual attraction]] and [[attachment theory|attachment]]. Attachment between adults is presumed to work on the same principles that lead an infant to become attached to its mother. The traditional psychological view sees love as being a combination of [[companionate love]] and passionate love. Passionate love is intense longing, and is often accompanied by [[physiological arousal]] (shortness of breath, rapid heart rate); companionate love is affection and a feeling of intimacy not accompanied by physiological arousal.

[[Werner Sombart]] placed that denaturation of love as the final stage of a destructive process of evolution, also present in other cultures outside the [[Western World]]: Firstly, love lost its individuality with [[Christianism]], which unified it and [[Theocracy|theocratized]] it: no love could be genuine if it didn't come from [[God]], if it wasn't approved by the [[Christian Church]]. A "flesh emancipation" process followed, which started with shy attempts and continued, with [[trobadour]]s, with a period of accented sensuality, of free and naive love development. Lastly, came a stage of great refinement and, as a coda, moral laxity and perversion.<ref name="Sombart">Werner Sombart.
